content.raw: It would also be greatly appreciate if you could provide the docker files used to build the images so that they can be used as references. Thank you.
content.html: It would also be greatly appreciate if you could provide the docker files used to build the images so that they can be used as references. Thank you.

content.raw:
Hi @{5cf75629ff02b50ea27b2817} , 

They way I understand is that the system is composed of three images. Two which we can’t modify and will be part of your system described [here](#!/osrf/subt/wiki/tutorials/cloudsim). And the third image is the one that will contain our solution/controller, described [here](#!/osrf/subt/wiki/tutorials/SystemSetupDocker). This third image could be build using the sample Dockerfile in [this link](#!/osrf/subt/wiki/tutorials/SystemSetupDocker), is that correct? We basically have to do modifications to that Dockerfile in order to incorporate our solution, and this Dockerfile has also the gazebo-ignition installed. 

Does this seem like what we need to do? The cloudsim description mentioned the third Solution Container but not how we are supposed to build it.  If we are not supposed to follow that Dockerfile for our Solution Container, could you provide a sample Dockerfile? 

Thank you!
content.html:
Hi @Alfredo Bencomo ,

They way I understand is that the system is composed of three images. Two which we can’t modify and will be part of your system described here. And the third image is the one that will contain our solution/controller, described here. This third image could be build using the sample Dockerfile in this link, is that correct? We basically have to do modifications to that Dockerfile in order to incorporate our solution, and this Dockerfile has also the gazebo-ignition installed.

Does this seem like what we need to do? The cloudsim description mentioned the third Solution Container but not how we are supposed to build it. If we are not supposed to follow that Dockerfile for our Solution Container, could you provide a sample Dockerfile?

Thank you!

content.raw: I think I was asking something pretty similar here [#!/osrf/subt/issues/113/what-packages-are-needed-to-use](#!/osrf/subt/issues/113/what-packages-are-needed-to-use). The other part \(except ign-transport\) is ROS communication. I believe those 2 things need to be inside the solution package in order to be able to talk to the other docker container.
content.html: I think I was asking something pretty similar here #!/osrf/subt/issues/113/what-packages-are-needed-to-use. The other part (except ign-transport) is ROS communication. I believe those 2 things need to be inside the solution package in order to be able to talk to the other docker container.

content.raw:
I’m also unsure how the solution container should look like. Does it really make sense to use the subt repository as a basis? There are also the descriptions and launch files for the robots included. So for me the subt has to be part of the simulation container but not the basis for the solution container. 

I would expect, that the subt\_seed repository amended with bridge and or communication stuff [has to](http://has.to) be the basis for the solution container. Or what do I miss?

content.raw:
Hey guys, I tried to put something together and I’m still in the middle of testing it \(a successful image submission to CloudSim will take at least one hour to get a log file back and much longer if submitted to a low-RTF environment\) but from local tests this should function and I’ll have confirmation back whenever the submission completes and I can check the log file.

I’ll fix any issues that arise whenever I get the log feedback but I want to get this out to you all as soon as possible since this could be a blocker for some of you. Check out the wiki article I wrote up over at [https://bitbucket.org/jgrogers/subt\_hello\_world/wiki/Simple%20Cloudsim%20Submission](https://bitbucket.org/jgrogers/subt_hello_world/wiki/Simple%20Cloudsim%20Submission) and let me know if you guys run into issues/have questions and I’ll update that page with your feedback.

Ideally this will accomplish request 1 from the issue and then I’ll have a secondary image for requset 2 probably by EOD tomorrow if the submission for request 1 works as intended.

Edit: My cloudsim submission did not result in vehicles doing anything although everything was loaded successfully without error.  I’m going to debug this with local cloudsim and I recommend all competitors do the same as the feedback loop with remote cloudsim is extremely lengthy.
content.html:
Hey guys, I tried to put something together and I’m still in the middle of testing it (a successful image submission to CloudSim will take at least one hour to get a log file back and much longer if submitted to a low-RTF environment) but from local tests this should function and I’ll have confirmation back whenever the submission completes and I can check the log file.

I’ll fix any issues that arise whenever I get the log feedback but I want to get this out to you all as soon as possible since this could be a blocker for some of you. Check out the wiki article I wrote up over at https://bitbucket.org/jgrogers/subt_hello_world/wiki/Simple%20Cloudsim%20Submission and let me know if you guys run into issues/have questions and I’ll update that page with your feedback.

Ideally this will accomplish request 1 from the issue and then I’ll have a secondary image for requset 2 probably by EOD tomorrow if the submission for request 1 works as intended.

Edit: My cloudsim submission did not result in vehicles doing anything although everything was loaded successfully without error. I’m going to debug this with local cloudsim and I recommend all competitors do the same as the feedback loop with remote cloudsim is extremely lengthy.

content.raw:
Hey @{557058:14b7fd50-d65a-47a8-825c-fa89681d07bd} , 

Thanks for putting this out! I tested it and works! It shows 4 vehicles starting and moving. Now the question is, this subt\_simple is based FROM nkoenig/subt-virtual-testbed. We have are compiling using cuda and opencv, so we would need to base our image FROM nvidia/cudagl:10.1-devel-ubuntu18.04.  Could we have access to the sample Docker file that was used to create nkoenig/subt-virtual-testbed? so we can add the other requirements we need? 

Or is this [Dockerfile](#!/osrf/subt/wiki/tutorials/SystemSetupDocker) a good start? 

Thanks again!
content.html:
Hey @Arthur Schang ,

Thanks for putting this out! I tested it and works! It shows 4 vehicles starting and moving. Now the question is, this subt_simple is based FROM nkoenig/subt-virtual-testbed. We have are compiling using cuda and opencv, so we would need to base our image FROM nvidia/cudagl:10.1-devel-ubuntu18.04. Could we have access to the sample Docker file that was used to create nkoenig/subt-virtual-testbed? so we can add the other requirements we need?

Or is this Dockerfile a good start?

Thanks again!

content.raw:
I believe the Dockerfile you linked is exactly what “nkoenig/subt-virtual-testbed” is \(I could be wrong so let’s confirm from @{557058:095b1e12-74ed-4e20-b44f-2f0745b616e0} \) .  The documentation for the “nkoenig/subt-virtual-testbed” can be found: [#!/osrf/subt/wiki/tutorials/SystemSetupDockerhub](#!/osrf/subt/wiki/tutorials/SystemSetupDockerhub) and [https://hub.docker.com/r/nkoenig/subt-virtual-testbed](https://hub.docker.com/r/nkoenig/subt-virtual-testbed) where it stemmed from Issue #107

A few of your options are \(as I understand them\):

1. Extend \(i.e. FROM\) “nkoenig/subt-virtual-testbed” to add your additional requirements in the extended Dockerfile \(i.e. building in “subt\_simple” before setting the entry point\)
2. Download and build the Dockerfile you linked and extend it \(i.e. FROM\) to add your additional requirements in the extended Dockerfile.
3. Download, modify, and build the Dockerfile you linked as well as set a valid entry point.
content.html:
I believe the Dockerfile you linked is exactly what “nkoenig/subt-virtual-testbed” is (I could be wrong so let’s confirm from @Nate Koenig ) . The documentation for the “nkoenig/subt-virtual-testbed” can be found: #!/osrf/subt/wiki/tutorials/SystemSetupDockerhub and https://hub.docker.com/r/nkoenig/subt-virtual-testbed where it stemmed from Issue #107

A few of your options are (as I understand them):

  1. Extend (i.e. FROM) “nkoenig/subt-virtual-testbed” to add your additional requirements in the extended Dockerfile (i.e. building in “subt_simple” before setting the entry point)
  2. Download and build the Dockerfile you linked and extend it (i.e. FROM) to add your additional requirements in the extended Dockerfile.
  3. Download, modify, and build the Dockerfile you linked as well as set a valid entry point.
